long_synopsis: Week 48 of Trump’s second term was a study in consolidation rather than spectacle. The Democracy Clock stayed at 8:11 p.m., yet moved 0.3 minutes closer to midnight as law, force, and story were drawn more tightly into the presidency’s orbit. The Supreme Court effectively legalized racial profiling in immigration enforcement, while ICE raids, travel-ban expansion, and coercive tactics against children hardened a tiered citizenship regime. National-security frameworks bled into ordinary governance through a fentanyl-as-WMD order, a naval blockade and terrorism label for Venezuela, and terrorism charges against anti-ICE protesters. Knowledge and oversight infrastructures were weakened: NCAR faced dismantling, university research funds were frozen, and public health agencies were captured by anti-vaccine leadership. Simultaneously, archives and memory were curated from above, with biased presidential plaques, a bid to rename the Kennedy Center, and Justice Department defiance of the Epstein Files Transparency Act. Courts, local governments, and civil society mounted real but insufficient resistance to this quiet tightening.
